description.text:
Gas cap retaining strap
This cures a minor but persistent annoyance.
My car is an unusual make and I'm posting this only for the sake of the idea.
No special instructions. 
This part has a large footprint, roughly a 5 inches square. The factory part was too wide for the platform, and I had to curve the piece connecting the two major sections. 
Make it out of nylon for flexibility, strength and chemical compatability.

My patio awning was begging for a Sonos PLAY:3 speaker, and the speaker was begging for a nice custom made yet stylish mounting bracket. 3D printer, do your job!  
This is sizewise just barely printable on a Replicator 2 - it is by far the biggest thing I have made. The conical speaker fits perfectly with a snap, and can easily be removed for the winter.  
The mounts are made to fit a 35 mm square bar, but the mounts themselves can relatively easily be modified for other dimensions.

Print with 4 extra shells to make it strong, then 10-15% infill. I have printed both at 0.1 mm and 0.27 mm layers, both work fine.   
Make one copy of the bracket and two copies each of the mounts. Break off the diagonal print supports at the end of the bracket (which holds the front of speaker). Mount using four 4 mm screws and nuts.  
I am not at all affiliated with Sonos, and I hope they do not mind that I used their good looking logo on the mount.
This is a 21 mm torch holder using the Klickfast body armour attachment. I have not tried it out yet so I do not know if it will work. You have been warned!

title: Temperance Union Lion Statue - lil' Las Vegas, New Mexico

description.text:
From "Save the LION" - a local Facebook group in the original Las Vegas, NEW MEXICO:

"Fountain Park” (The Triangle, Lion Park) started as an open patch of ground where wagons parked. In 1896, the Women's Christian Temperance Union employed a local stonemason, Angelo de Tullio, to design and sculpt a fountain. They hoped to offer an alternative watering hole to the neighboring saloons. De Tullio’s fountain is dominated by an angelic-looking lion. This stiffly-rendered piece of folk sculpture spurted water from its mouth into a trough below. The fountain represents one work of the local community of immigrant Italian stonemasons, and as Lynn Perrigo has suggested: "is emblematic of the past interplay of two facets of local culture -- the excesses of the boom era and the determination of dedicated local women to create a wholesome environment in Las Vegas."

From Architecture & Preservation in Las Vegas by Chris Wilson:
The Lion Fountain consists of a base, pedestal, basin, plinth block, and lion sculpture all carved from local reddish-brown sandstone typically referred to as “Romeroville Stone”. It suffers from ‘spalling’ the delamination of the stone from freezing and thawing during the seasons. The upper lip, right paw and tail are in need of repair and graffiti needs to be cleaned. The fountain pipes are all intact and could possibly be restored to a water fountain.

The first version (LLV_lion_fixed_02.STL) is rather large (around 28mb), and has some problems around the base. If you choose to print that version, use a raft and no support & you should be fine.

The second version (temperancelion-_las_vegas_nm.STL) has a much lower poly count, and has a flat base added from TinkerCad. It should be a little easier to print, but there is slightly less detail.

I have printed both versions on a Printrbot Simple Metal using Cura with great results.

description.text:
I've created these slightly impractical alternatives to business cards based off the parametric Duplo brick. Printing a full brick takes about an hour so instead I created a flat base plate by removing the "nibbles" in openScad and then used the Ponoko tutorial listed below to create a typeface (Herron Condensed works great) to add the text. I can now hot swap details onto the bricks depending on what information I want to give out. More details and pics at
http://www.brendandawes.com/project/momento-bricks/ The MK6 Stepstruder really makes a difference when printing stuff with text - it's a wonderful piece of kit. I also used the new 1.7mm filament - nuclear green is very cool.

You'll need to create a typeface - there's a great tutorial on the Ponoko blog: http://blog.ponoko.com/2011/06/30/adding-3d-fonts-to-openscad/ Then simply import the stl file below and place your text.

The infamous Halo Energy sword! Print in white, light blue, or glow in the dark!
This is an awesome 12 print design that is about 3 ft (0.9 m) long
Each print should interlock via holes and studs
Total print is about 72 hours with 0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill and 2 shells (look at instructions for further print info)

If there is anything I should fix, let me know

Print all the blade parts twice with rafts and no supports.
Blades 3,4, and 5 all fit on one print for me on the Makerbot 5th Gen.

Print the each handle part once with supports.
These both fit for me as well on one print.

Ever been at a party where there are no seats left and you're standing holding your beer and a plate of food with no way to eat? Well with this handy contraption you'll be able to hold your beer and plate in one hand and eat or drink with the other.

This is not an original idea, but I couldn't find the original one I had seen about a year ago to print so I made my own from scratch. This is still a work in progress (I'm printing the first one out now). But if anyone has any changes they can make or want to make, feel free to take the files and change them up, just let me know so that maybe I can use a better version of this thing.

--Ok, I printed one out and I ran into a couple of problems with my printer and found some changes I need to make to the design. As soon as I fix my printer (looks like I need to replace the z axis bearrings and printed parts so time to order some better bearrings) I'll make the changes that are required and hopefully print a good working set and post that.

description.text:
This is a track made to fit the Adafruit Neopixel LED flexible strips. I've used the 60 pixels / meter strip for the design but it should work for the other Neopixel strips as well.

This design is meant to have the pixels facing away from the viewer and placed on some sort of mounting board that will reflect the light back through the plastic providing an interesting diffuse glowing affect without the normal glare associated with these very bright LED strips. Along with the tracks, I've included end-caps that can be used to hide where the wires will connect to the Neopixel strip, a coupler to join two tracks together for longer runs, a corner joint and a three-way joint. These add some architectural interest to the tracks.

Orientation is important for the tracks which are designed to printed in halves (the same track piece printed twice). They should be printed with the outside of the track on the build plate lengthwise. The LED strip would then be inserted into the finished track piece from the top and another track piece added on top of that to sandwich the LED strip. The couplers should be printed with the top on the build plate.

These parts are design to be printed using PLA, preferrable a translucent color or natural with a 0.4mm diameter nozzel with a 0.2mm layer thickness and 1 shell. You can choose whatever infill you like. I printed them using a Marketbot Replicator 2 generation 4 using Matterhackers Natural PLA and 205 degrees C.

For single color printers -
Print parts in the correct colors and fit them together!

This pulley was designed as part of a project looking into the increases in strength and stiffness which can be achieved through using internal channels accommodating fibre reinforcements (carbon is stated, however a variety of other materials may be used, e.g. basalt, kevlar, flax, steel cable).

The design process involved analysis of force lines through an unreinforced part, along with topological optimisation to determine the optimum positioning of the fibres.

When reinforced with carbon it can be expected for the pulley to fail at approx. 0.8 tonnes or 8000N.

Layer Height - 0.2
Material - PLA(Stiffer) or ABS
Supports - None if printer bridges well
Infill - 25% +

To thread the fibres through the channels create a 'nib' of around 3 - 5cm on a length of carbon fibre tow (approx. 1 - 1.5m) using a good super glue (liquid usually works best). Bond the end of the carbon tow which has not been glued to the pulley in the middle of one of the legs and proceed to thread the carbon around the part. To finish, once no more fibres can fit into the channel, cut off the nib ensuring that the end is glued also in the middle of one of the legs - this is a relatively low stress area.

Apply epoxy resin or other ensuring that it penetrates all fibres and cure.

Designs created alongside Dr. Hadley Brooks.

title: Wall mount for ASUS RT-AC66U WiFi Router

description.text: This is a simple adapter plate to allow for wall mounting an Asus RT-AC66U router. There are two holes for countersunk screws (#6 size) which go into the wall, and the little square flanges engage with the holes in the back of the router. The semi circular cutouts are to allow ventilation. This was developed in 123D Design Online, and the editable file is here.

The object as oriented is upside-down, so that the flanges can print without support (and aligned with the strongest dimension of the filament).  
To install, turn it around, so that the flat side is facing the wall and the two "legs" are pointing down. Put a #6 screw with a countersunk head in one of the screw holes and screw it in. Use a level to make sure the bracket is level, and then put in the second screw. Hang the router on the flanges and pull down to seat it. (Don't pull too hard!)

title: Dual iPad 3 and iPhone 4S charging stand with speaker amplifier.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My first attempt at designing and making something for my Mendel Max 1.5  
This is an iPad 3 and iPhone 4S combination stand with speaker amplifier for both the iPad and the iPhone. I have a dual charger connected to it so I can charge both of my gadgets at the same time.   
It'll fit iPhone 3, 3gs, 4, 4S, iPad 2 ( a bit loose thanks to comment from downeym), iPad3, and at least one model of the the iTouch.  
Any comments feel free.

This is a large print and it barely fit on my 200mm x 200mm print bed.  
Set the skirt to print 2mm from the object and that should prevent the print from printing off the print bed.   
Print with support material for the bidges over the speaker outputs.  
On my Mendel Max 1.5, this print took approximately 10 hours using Slic3r and Pronterface (using Slic3r default settings from 30mm/s to 60mm/s with support material, fill density 0.2) . I used PLA (185C) on a heated bed (60C constant) sprayed with a light coat of Aquanet hairspray.

title: LS 3020 HPC Laser Cutter Exaust Fan

description.text:
Based on tiefpunkt's basic design, I have remade it in openSCAD to be parametric and arranged to fit on the bed of the LS3020 laser cutter.

I have made mine out of 5mm perxpex and it fits together well.

The hole is 100mm, you can work the wire of standard 100mm ducting tube through the hole, and tape in on the inside. There are also some optional 3mm screw holes if you want to attach an adapter of some sort.

The box's fit is tight enough to hold from friction alone, though I have since used some poly cement to fix it and seal it. So far it seems to be working perfectly.

title: Bokode @ Home

description.text: You've heard of Bokode http://web.media.mit.edu/~ankit/bokode/ , right? The long distance microscope that lets you see detailed barcodes and data with only a digital camera? The one that uses a tiny 3mm lenslet to display highly accurate position and distance information from several meters away? Yeah. That one.

Take a look at the writeup here:
http://sinbox.org/bokode
Get some sample microprint patterns here:
http://sinbox.org/bokode/bokode%20samples.pdf
Get the microprint printed here (~$80):
http://www.pageworks.com/transparencymasks.html
Follow the assembly diagram in the DXF. This design is scaled for .11\" acrylic, 4/40 .375" machine screws and nuts, and you\'ll need the lens out of a webcam, a power source, an led, and some tape for calibrating the focus.

comments.text:
Cool. Another version of this is a passive one with retro-reflector would work with just a camera flash. No need for charging it or for a led...
They are right to realize that it's not the data capacity that's the killer app but the sheer invisibility to humans + accurate angular information for AR applications. Capacity is a nice bonus: barcodes or and other type of tagging systems are usually online systems, if you have an ID you can lookup the rest in a database.

author: gianteye

description.text:
A (parametric) buckle that you can attach to your camera strap, which lets you (hopefully) stop losing your lens cap.
The STL is sized for a 58mm lens cap, and a ~40mm strap width.
The printing layers make for a great friction catch for the lens cap.  But there's a designed-in lip overhang to make it a little more aggressive.

Change the parameters; print; dismantle strap; thread on buckle; reattach strap; take pictures; lose lens cap (less) Parameters:
  • lens diameter
  • buckle thickness, height
  • strap gap, width
  • mount height, width
  • mount lip tweaks
  • fill the buckle back, or leave X'ed (i.e. save plastic)
    • 2011-07-24: MK2 openscad script
  • allows multiple holders-in-one.
  • cutout in buckle to handle straps that are not threadable

comments.text: For those asking how to change the scad file for different lens sizes. There are 3 things I changed, 1) the lens_diameter parameter, which I set to the full width of the lens cap - edge to edge. 2) Changed the first attribute in the capmount function to be the same number as the lens_diameter parameter. 3) Then changed the second capmount function to be the size of the lens which is usually written on the back of your lens cover for your camera. Hope that helps.

description.text:
This thing is for: KOHLER Levity Sliding Bath and Shower Doors

This plastic thing broke when I installed my bathtub door. The original is made out of VERY brittle plastic, it broke with very little force!

The replacement kit is very expensive:
INSIDE PANEL ROLLER KIT - 1213185
http://www.us.kohler.com/us/INSIDE-PANEL-ROLLER-KIT/productDetail/Service-Parts/966112.htm?skuId=966087&hash=id%3Dfilters-1%26startIndex%3D40%26scrollTop%3D0

I am pretty sure the outside panel uses the same plastic thing.

So I designed and 3D printed a replacement. It fits perfectly, and since this is on the inside of the roller, it is not even visible after you install it.

I printed it at 95% infill to make sure it does not break again.

author: CVMichael

description.text:
A remix of user MacGyver's BORT license plate from the episode "Itchy & Scratchy Land" from Season 5 of the Simpsons.

This model keeps the words and the plate separate so the plate can be printed in one color (white) and the words in another (red) right over.

Technically, though, in the show the words "Itchy & Scratchy Land" were in black so I included all sets of words separately so they can printed that way if desired.

1) Print the plate first and leave it adhered to the bed.
2) Set the Z offset to the thickness of the plate. You may want to get an official value from your printer. Mine was 0.4mm off the bed.
3) Slice the 'words' STL and do a dry run without the temperature GCode so the nozzle won't melt the plate.
4) Once you're satisfied with the placement of the letters on the plate, slice and print for real.

This collection of parts was made to help organize an electronics test area by assembling test benches out of dowels.

Additional accessories already provided in this set include a base for a Texas Instruments launchpad, and a low cost precision digital power supply.

Note that the other files are dependent on TkrTestbench.scad

Supplied files are OpenScad source files.

This is a major update. The general model has not changed but all source files have changed and some have been added.

When I started trying to do the instructions, I realized that I really hadn't thought this through. I also recognized that I had not adopted clear conventions, so I started anew, addressing naming, documentation, structure, and conventions. I also learned how to use Doxygen effectively with openscad and have generated pretty good documentation.

One of the conventions is that each library now has a contents module intended to show the contents of the file, and that module is active by default, so you can double click on any file and you will get the contents shown the the images here.

For complete documentation, look here https://yourdevelopmentteam.com/things/TinkertoyTestbench/, or unzip TinkertoyTestbenchDoc..zip and open TinkertoyTestbench.chm. If there are problems, see the included readme.

All source files are OpenScad.

Open example.scad in OpenScad. It contains a kit module as an example as well as commented out calls to most of the parts.

The only premade .stl provided is a rendering of that kit.

For complete documentation, look here https://yourdevelopmentteam.com/things/TinkertoyTestbench/, or unzip TinkertoyTestbenchDoc..zip and open TinkertoyTestbench.chm. If there are problems, see the included readme.

title: Drawing Compass That works with computer thumbscrews

description.text:
My gf wrote down 'compass' on the grocery list, which for some reason I interpreted as a navigational compass....  
Anyway I downloaded aylr's model but made some adjustments so it would print properly & made a second file with larger holes to accommodate standard computer thumbscrews.

Finagled a screw into the fixed original design (although I recommend you redesign that side to fit whatever you're going to use for the metal tip) via jerry-rigging some wing nuts, then used a motherboard stand + computer thumbscrews for the 'thumbscrew' piece.

comments.text: Thanks for this design!  I need to adapt a compass for a blind student to use and this design is going to really save me time!

title: Simple Spacer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you need a spacer RIGHT NOW, this is the model for you!

Customize the three dimensions of this spacer (inner diameter, thickness, and height), and -voila!- you have finished!

This is my very first customizable thing, so I kept it simple. Enjoy!

I know, this is a very confusing model, so I will make the instructions as detailed as possible:

  1. Click "Open in Customizer"
  2. Chose the diameter of the spacer (tolerance not included)
  3. Chose the thickness of the space
  4. Chose the height of the spacer
  5. Click "Create Thing"
  6. Download your spacer from there
  7. Print your spacer (3D printer not included)

description.text:
NOTE version 3 has been added with more space for the flight camera and an oval slot in the front to allow the camera to tilt more
Team High Society would like to share version 3 of it's ZMR Shield.
Check out our you tube channel for awesome flight videos and how-to's! https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpPhxOeasW_W03eQeW7KCgg

Print this out in ninja flex and it is the perfect protector of all your quads internal goodness!

I flew into a tree and some one of the branches got inside the quad and really tore up some of the wiring, this solves the problem and may also make the quad more aerodynamic!

Print with Ninjaflex @ 0% infill, 3 top and bottom layers, and 1 shell!

I have printed at .2 or .3....both work great whatever your printer does best.

If you use the front carbon piece to mount your camera use version 3 as it has the room to accommodate the fiber mount, if you have a camera that swivels and is in a case you can use the smaller v1

Have a great day! :-)

For the assembly all you do is print out the case and two 80 mm. Fan guards,one for the inside to keep wires out of the fan and one for the outside to keep you and others out. As for the opening of the fan you will have to remove the supports around the opening, then the guard will sit their. And then their is the stock fan on the printer you will have to reverse it to push air out instead of in. The 80 mm. will bring air in. It does a much better job of cooling in this way. If any changes are in order,Please let me know. Of course the RSDOC. files are included for anyone that may want to edit this to their likening.Enjoy :-)

title: Kerbal Space Program Logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This weeks 3DPick goes to Netram for his request for Kerbal Space Program!

Kerbal Space Program (commonly abbreviated as KSP) is a space flight simulator developed by Squad for Linux, OS X, Windows, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One. In the game, players control a space program, build and fly spacecraft under physics simulation, and explore celestial bodies. The first publicly available version was released on the official Kerbal Space Program store on June 24, 2011. The game also became available on Steam's early access program on March 20, 2013. The game was officially released out of beta on April 27, 2015. The game has large support for game mods and a large community to create them, which developed shortly after the game's initial release. Notable members of the space industry have taken an interest in the game, including NASA and Elon Musk of SpaceX. - Wikipedia

update as of 29-Aug-2015, i made the ear-ends thicker and the ear-lengths shorter so the zipties fit snugly. It still has the 3mm lip around the motor. Also, I added pictures of the actual printed mounts.

There are 2 different mounts, note the hole placements. This is so when you mount the DYS 1806, the motor cable are angled so it points to the general direction of the multi rotor's body for cleaner cabling.

I deliberately mount this about an inch from the tip of the boom so when i crash, the boom actually protects the propeller from hitting the ground. a makeshift prop protector ;)

This is the motor mount of the DYS 1806 2300kv motor.

The width of the ears have been set to 10mm to fit the 10mm wooden booms I used on my tricopter so the ziptie will bite it properly.

Also, i added a 3mm to the motor disk so it has a protective lip around the motor incase it bumps into things.

This was my first foray into using OpenSCAD which I really like since its very accurate.

author: thumthum

description.text:
Remix of a figure by Harry Baere found on another site (link below). Added figure base to stl via netfabb software and resized to fit the dungeons and figures for my games.

https://www.youmagine.com/designs/the-undead

In the STL file, you would see the body and a cap. The cap is separate because it is hard to support the roof on a hollow tube without supporting material. After printed, glue the cap to the body. It must be air tight to produce the correct notes. Epoxy adhesive is possibly a good choice, as it allows you to adjust a little bit when you glue it and dries in 5 mins. Wait for a few hours before the cap is totally secured on the body. Now the tube is closed on both ends, play on the mouth hole in the middle, and hold the flute with your hands from below.
Chi (篪) is a flute used in Chinese court music since Zhou dynasty. The earliest example of this instrument was found in the Tomb of Marquis Yi of Zeng built in around 433BC.
Contrary to most flutes, the mouth hole is between the middle or one third of the pipe, while the two hands hold it from below. Another interesting feature is that the pipe is closed at both ends. Chinese flautist Zhao Song-ting (趙松庭) has reconstructed this instrument in the 20th century and written a piece for it. There is also a replica of this instrument in Confucius temple in Taipei, Taiwan.
This is an experiment to understand the acoustic and the measurements of the instrument. The relationship of fingering and pitch on this instrument is quite unpredictable. It seems that the two sides of the tube compete to make a sound, and only one side would actually produce a note when you blow. The position of the holes doesn't seem to affect the pitch as much as the size does.
I have put the fingering chart in the link below, if anyone with knowledge in acoustics can help to explain the relationship between fingering and pitch please feel free to contact me. One could adjust the pitch by slightly adjusting the lips' blowing angle, by rolling it outward or inward a little bit, or by using half holes.

Fingering chart:
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/wofi7lj3z9q0z6n/AACrAe0uHMhI7NeK3OC81BcWa?dl=0

And here is a demonstration of how it sounds like:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WVz2Y5z56Ms&feature=youtu.be

title: Victorinox Extra Driver Bit carrier for leather pouches.

description.text:
This little goodie is designed to fit into a leather pouch suited for a Victoinox Cybertool lite.

It's intended to carry 21 X 4mm driver bits, 1 X Micro SD card, and a Micro USB wifi adaptor (or mouse receiver etc)

It also houses 5 X 10mmX2mm Rare earth Neodymium magnets on the base.

All things I use on a job, alongside my Cybertool.
I purchased a second Leather belt pouch to house it.

As usual, autocad and Inventor files are included for the remix specialists.

THIS DESIGN IS FOR ABS!!!
As with many of my designs, tolerances are tight, PLA will not cut it for accuracy on this one.
This design can and will show up any calibration issues with your machine, so please check carefully and methodically before complaining that this doesn't fit.

You will need a couple of very short (5mm long X 3mm diameter) stainless screws. They should cut their own thread as they are screwed in (not too tight!)

I gave this a very quick wash in acetone once the 3mm screws were set in place, and left to dry in a room temp area. This helped secure the bond between layers, and gave me a chance to correct alignment issues with the lid.

any more questions - leave a comment - just please, no trolling this time, it gets really old, and makes me regret uploading projects.

title: uStepper robot arm - Obsolete! (See summary)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Revision 3 is released! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1774473

This design is obsolete, please refer to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1398215

VIDEO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ebjdsye-PE

The gears are modified versions of the "OpenSCAD Herringbone Wade's Gears Script" "(c) 2011, Christopher "ScribbleJ" Jansen" - So I cannot take credit for these well designed gears.

Visit https://github.com/uStepper/uStepper for detailed instructions and design files!

You will need aluminum rod in both Ø 15mm (~13mm inner) and Ø6mm.
Besides that, a couple of bearings are used:
4 pcs. 608ZZ
10 pcs. 624ZZ
2 pcs. 625ZZ

The tubes were bought at the local hardware store called Bauhaus.
The tube lengths for the two Ø15 are 170mm and 310mm, the Ø6 are 270mm, 220mm and 210mm (that is the lengths they are when I cut them - not including the printed ends). NOTE the tube lengths will not give you the parallelograms making the end actuator stay aligned with the base - I am working on instructions showing how to assemble the arm and dimension tube lengths!.

M3 x 20mm = 24 (I cut them in length to fit - if it is necessary)
M4 x 20mm = 4
M4 x 30mm = 1
M4 x 35mm = 1
M4 x 50mm = 1
M5 x 40mm = 1
M8 threaded rod 70mm or 65mm if it's a bolt
M8 x 35mm = 1

All lengths are of the threaded part of the bolts - not including the head (but that is also what's normally stated on the boxes you buy them in)

Besides that you will need nuts and spacers. Between the two main gears I used a lot of spaces to keep the apprpriate distance between the gears. I realize that finding some aluminium tube with inner diameter of 8mm would look better and do the job just as good.

comments.text: Instructions are now available at the uStepper Git repository: https://github.com/uStepper/uStepper

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3DULF7YSQh1

title: Invisible Airport Express / Apple TV Wall Mount (adaptable)

description.text:
I have some airport express devices to expand my network and I wanted to mount them on the wall. There are several options for this already on Thingiverse (referenced below) but I wanted to have an invisible wall mount. So here's my contribution to the pile of mounting options.

Assembly and installation video: https://vid.me/1xQJ

This also works for the Apple TV device (I believe mine is a 3rd Gen version).

Parts and Materials

  • Three #4 pan head screws where the head is 2.5mm thick or less.
  • 5 minute epoxy
  • 3D printed centering ring, glue mask, object plate, wall plate

Process

Attach centering ring to device. Place glue mask inside the centering ring. Apply epoxy. On the underside of the plate that attaches to the device, apply epoxy without going past or filling the ooze channel. Remove glue mask. Use a thin layer to prevent oozing.

Place the object plate that will be attached to the device in the centering ring, open end pointed toward the side with all of the sockets if you want the cord to hang downward. If you are careful about the amount of glue you use, you can leave the centering ring in place. If you fear side ooze, remove the centering ring or it may get glued in place.

If you get side ooze into the center channel you must remove everything, clean off the epoxy with acetone, and start over. If you fill that channel with ooze, it won't slide onto the wall plate. Finally, place a weight on the piece and let it cure (one hour for 5 minute epoxy).

Screw the wall plate to a wall with #4 pan head screws, and slide the device on the wall plate. This sounds sort of involved, but when I videotaped the process, it took just under six minutes, most of which I cut out for the demo video.

0.5 mm Nozzle

My printer (Lulzbot Mini) has a 0.5 mm nozzle installed. If you have a printer with a smaller nozzle, the parts might be a tad loose. You can either scale the wall plate up to account for this in your slicer, or you could edit the source files which I have included (freeCAD native file format). You may also have to scale down the centering tool to remove unwanted play.

Stick on Anything

There is no reason this process couldn't be used on any device or object (of appropriate weight). I have included the centering square without any arms if you would like a simple way to create an invisible mount for some other object. Just make your own arms and stick the centering plate on them.

Other Types of Wall Mounts

The invisible nature of my mount is cool, but what is less cool is the necessity to permanently mar your device by epoxying stuff to it. The following wall mounts require no modifications to your device:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:146026
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:218720

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329873

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:621382 (only blue image)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820274 (only blue image)

If you know of more, please let me know and I'll add to the list.

description.text:
it is sized for my middle finger,you can scale it up or down if you need,

Designed it for a browning pump action,wel suitable for airsoft as the dimensions are very similar, the light is the one flooded on ebay, chinese made led hand lamp (with the mode hi low beam and strobe) modified with a pad switch becomes a cheap tac light (to be honest,use a surefire device if you want a decent tac light) but as a budget,this works just fine.
print 2 of them and bolt together,if you want it with rounded edges le me know.

IMPORTANT
Check back for updates as I revise the files This is an amazing blooming flower! Turn the gear on the bottom and the flower blooms, exposing the beautiful flower within! Original purpose for this design was creating something to turn rotational movement into linear movement, using something that could be printed on a Makerbot. Figured the easiest to design was something screw-like, but with overhang restrictions, I was unsure whether a tight screw design would work. And it turns out it does! DESIGN VERSIONS
There are two different versions.
First version uses glue and filament as the hinges for the petals. Pros to this is the petals are much tighter, and don't wiggle around alot. Con is that it requires more glue.
Second version uses links as the hinges. Pro is that less glue is needed. Cons are that it wiggles alot more, because the links require some give to snap into place. Also, when snapping into the base, the base links have a significant chance of breaking off. I have added supports and fixes to prevent this from happening, but there is still a chance. Extra stl for broken links to glue on in case this happens. DIFFERENT GEARS
NOTE: Applies only to large flowers
In order to turn the gears, I designed two different gear systems.
First version allows the entire bottom to turn, but is more difficult to get on the base.
Second version is easier to get on, but the gear is slightly more difficult to get to, and could prove more difficult for some people to turn. FILES
Files are placed in zip files, for easy organization. Credit where credit is due, flower in center is from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5883 Internal screw is 1 rotation per 20mm rise.
Design files included.
(I apologize for the messy designs, didn't organize or rename anything in the ipt files :P ) NOTE:
For those who want to design a different center piece without the cap, the rod in the center is 5mm diameter. This way you can design the hole directly into your variation. UPDATES UPDATE 7/7/2011:
Edited Version 1-Large Flower-Base updated.
EDITS: Forgot to edit the top ring of the small petals, they were 1mm too wide. Also the main circle of the base is several millimeters too small, causing the small petals to be too close to the center shaft. Sorry to those who have already printed this. UPDATE 7/8/2011:
Edited version of Gear 1 for Large Flower uploaded.
1 zip with all current STL Files as of 7/8/2011 uploaded.
EDITS: Center shaft is not long enough on Gear 1 bottom (Gear 2 is fine). Really sorry I missed this.(Note it says v1, but it is also for v2) UPDATE 7/9/2011:
Edited version of large flower petal for v1 uploaded.....hinge was too big....
Re-upload of Large V1 zip with correct STL Files.
Revised version updated. UPDATE 7/12/2011:
Makerbot out of commission ATM, can't test any of the un-built files, but they should work just fine. UPDATE 7/22/2011:
Hooray! Got my replacement parts, TOM is back up and running, will start printing some new flowers in the next few days! If you find any other mistakes, please message me.

Print 4 of each of the links, and 4 each of the petals.
Print 1 of everything else. Everything is designed to print supportless.
Cool->Slowdown recommended, used 10 sec for ABS and 6 for PLA. NOTE
COMPLETED 100%: Large V2 and Small V1
DESIGNED BUT NOT PRINTED: Large V1 and Small V2. Small V2 should work, had a few problems with Large V1 and am currently printing to see if changes are correct. INTERNAL SPINNER NOTE
Internal spinner is designed to be inserted in bottom. Twisting extends it up and down. Catches on both the base and the spinner to prevent it from exiting all the way through the top. There are 3 different ways to insert the spinner through the bottom, 1 is correct.
Make sure the long rod on top is pointed up.
Main body should spin through the hole in the top, if not, its not in the correct screw lines, take it out, turn it slightly so the screw lines match up differently, and try again. Will get it eventually :) . LARGE FLOWER ASSEMBLY
Insert internal spin into base from bottom.
GEAR 1: Line up bottom with spinner, push all the way through. Take two of the top pieces, slid in from the side, making sure they lock the bottom in place. Glue top to base.
GEAR 2: Line up top with spinner, push all the way through. Take bottom and press against bottom, making sure the top gear is in place. Glue bottom to base. These should allow the gears to spin freely while keeping it attached to the base. Spinning should move the internal spinner up and down. VERSION 1:
Cut several pieces of filament, long enough to get through the base and the petals. Slide these through one side of base, then petal, out the other side. Glue filament to base, making sure not to get any glue on petal. This should act as a hinge for the petals to move on. Big petals first, then small.
VERSION 2:
Snap the petals into the base. Big petals, then little petals on top. Snap the small links onto the small petals, and the big links onto the big petals. Make sure the big links are INSIDE the small petals so they dont get in the way.
Slide the big internal link onto the rod. Hook it up with the links joined to the big petals. Slide the small internal link, the thicker side down, onto the rod. Hook up to links on small petal.
Slide cap down rod, glue in place. Place flower on the cap, and glue in place. And your done! Breath a sigh of relief. SMALL FLOWER ASSEMBLY
Exactly the same as the large flower, but you only have one layer of petals to worry about. ANY PROBLEMS -> ASK QUESTIONS!!!
Happy building!

This is version 2 of my nozzle light. It uses two 12V LED strip segments wired in series to the 24V supply via a 100ma fuse. The front and rear LEDs light up the area under the nozzle enabling you to clearly see the layers being printed.The rear strip holders are slim so not to catch on the rear Z axis guides. The holders are designed to clip onto the nozzle carriage so as not to require any permanent modifications.

Parts

  1. 2 x LED Segmnets. I cut 2 from a roll on e-Bay." Super Bright White LED Strip Light Waterproof 5m 12V 5050 SMD Flexible 300LED"

  2. In-line fuse holder.

  3. Hook-up Wire

  4. 2 x 2 Pin connectors if you wish to make easily removable. I used Jaycar PT4452.

Remember to wire the 2 LEDs in series NOT parallel as the supply is 24V and the LEDs are 12.

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner
Needed a servo for a gimbal I am working on. Ordered these from hobbyking and made a simple 3d model. Not perfect but good for 3d modelling.

I did not understand what the hole of the extruder gear is for, so I tought that it is a hole for a handle or something like that.
I found out what it is for, but I tought that a handle would still be nice. I am not really good at 3D-Modelling, but I did my best and created a handle for the Ultimaker Extruder-gear. It works very well and I am really happy with the result, even tough it doesn't make sense to have a handle, to be honest. But it looks nice :) All you need is a printer with a good resolution and one washer.
I printed it on my new Ultimaker with the following settings: 40mm/s speed
0.1 mm layer height
wall thickness 0.35 mm (using a 4mm-nozzle)
fill-density 20%
retraction: on I have also included a GCode-file for the very lazy ones ;) The parts came out of the printer relatively properly, I only had to remove some small pieces where the retraction was a little bit to slow. The assembling is very easy, notice that it is normal that you have to put some serious force on the handle to stick the two printed parts together. the smaller piece has to be sticked from the back of the gear and the bigger piece needs to be pressed on it from the front-side of the gear. The side with the bigger hole needs to touch the gear, the bigger opening has to point at you. Before you remount the gear to the Ultimaker, put a second washer between the feeder and the gear- the handle touches one screw of the extruder if you do not. This could case problems while extruding. If you have mounted the handle once, it sticks very well, please notice that it MIGHT be possible that the handle breaks if you remove it - it is made to stay on it's place even if you use some serious force while you turn the gear... I tested it on the original Ultimaker-gear but I think that most of the replacements should work aswell. I included the original skp-files, a fixed stl-file and the GCode I printed with. This is my very first thing I upload on Thingiverse, please feel free to test it out and improve it if you see the need of it. Thanks for reading, downloading and commenting :)

description.text:
Bust of Anne-Marie-Louise Thomas de Domangeville, Artist Jean Antoine Houdon, 1780, Marble, Art Institute of Chicago
Scan taken with a Structure Sensor and Itseez 3D app.
It was edited some in Meshlab, Blender, and Meshmixer. Never quite finished, but here it is. I've also submitted it to MyMiniFactory/Scan The World, so I can't wait to see what their artists do with it. Their models are amazing!

Update: I have done some more editing and printed her up. I removed the first model.
Update2: I went back over the model and made some changes, but I'm not printing it out again. It's also simplified. I apologize for the huge file sizes.

anne_marie_update.stl is the model that is the closest to the original sculpture (as close as I could get it, anyway). You will need supports for her clothing.
anne_marie_update_min_supp_needed.stl is the cheater-version that needs as few supports as possible. Use this if you don't care about getting it as authentic as you can and would rather have an easier print. No supports are needed until you reach her chin.
anne_marie_min_supp_mm.stl has supports drawn in (by hand in Meshmixer) if you're interested. I used this one to print what is in the pics I uploaded. That being said, there was some elbow grease that went into sanding the model before I photographed it.

comments.text: You probably have other issues going on. Over time the frames will fatigue and wobble. You can brace the frame too. Make sure it's on a solid surface that doesn't allow the machine to wobble. Don't use shock absorbers, that makes it worse.

comments.text: Wow, a BIG improvement. I can't help but think the fact that these help is a sign that the z-bearings aren't doing their job, I would have previously thought it'd be better to constrain the threaded rod as little as possible so the wobbles aren't transmitted to the X-axis, but apparently not.

comments.text: I'm using Nophead's z-couplers with some really soft tubing and i'm getting no wobble at all. No constrains needed.

comments.text: top and bottom for me btw. Also I've found it better to put some heatshrink over the threaded rod, and really force the bearings onto that for the best reduction in wobble. I also fitted the couplings afterwards, which seemed to align them better.
comments.author: jamesglanville

comments.text: brilliant! going to print myself 2 of these now :)
comments.author: Blobber

comments.text: I use them at the top and the bottom, just to be sure.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: moving them to top was a huge improvement for me. the before/after objects for tall objects are dramatic. thanks.
comments.author: ScribbleJ

comments.text: One of my very first upgrades, thanks ! :)

comments.text: You've bolted down the Z motors, havent you? thats why you need this :-)
comments.author: josefprusa

comments.text: when you have wobble plus motors arent bolted down you can get variable layer height, because the motor goes up instead of the x axis. I think this is an excellent idea, better than having the bottom of the bars floating.

Samsung fridge ice lever
The fixing hole will need a small amount of filing for a perfect fit

This is the bowden extruder I designed for my new CoreXZ printer (QuorXZ). I have included the necessary SCAD files if you want to modify it. It is designed to be mounted (without a spacer) to a Nema 17 motor through 6mm or 10mm MDF, or directly to a motor using one or both 5mm spacer(s) included. See instructions for necessary parts to build.

8-29-15: Added Thumb-screw tension adjuster. (Also modified the lever a bit to better fit the thumb-screw.)

9-1-15: Modified Thumb-screw adjuster.

9-3-15: Added tabbed spacer with M5 mounting holes.

9-15-15: Added printed barrel w/nut insert (untested).

9-16-15: Modified barrel w/nut insert.

NOTE: As I modify this thing, I will REPLACE older files with the newer files. What is here is the latest iteration.

Watch the extruder in action on my new printer (QuorXZ) in the video below.

You will need several parts to complete this thing as designed.
(1) SMC KQ2S04-M5A push-fit connector (Amazon)
(1) MK8 hobbed gear - 9mm OD X 11mm (Ebay - Leap3D)
(1) M5 X 15 low-profile screw (OpenBuilds)
(2) 5mm X 10mm X 1mm precision shims (OpenBuilds)
(1) 5mm tapered tee-nut (OpenBuilds)
(1) 5mm X 16mm X 5mm ball bearing (OpenBuilds 625 2RS)
(1) 5mm X 10mm X 4.2mm ball bearing (OpenBuilds Mini Ball Bearing)
(1) 12mm X 8mm diam Barrel-nut with M4 threads (EBay - screwseller0178)
(1) M4 X 30mm screw for clamp
(1) M4 nut (if using printed barrel instead of metal barrel-nut)
(1) M4 X 12mm (by 6mm OD) spring for clamp (ThingiBox.com)
(4) M3 screws of appropriate length (40mm if mounting through 10mm MDF, 35mm if using 6mm MDF or one printed spacer directly to motor)

NOTE: Substituting hardware will probably require modification of printed parts - spacing is compact and tolerances are fairly tight.

I printed all parts with 30% infill. Cover may need to be printed with supports - others do not (YMMV). (Lever, cover, and tabbed spacer will need to be re-oriented. Thumb-screw adjuster should probably NOT be re-oriented.) The printed barrel is untested. I think it should be printed with 100% infill and sanded smooth.

Use a 2mm or 5/64" drill bit to clean the filament path. I used a 10-24 self-tapping screw to start the threads for the M5 push-fit connector (I may redesign that hole to make it easier to tap with the connector itself).

[Note: To properly render the cad objects, all .scad files must be in the same directory.]

This jigsaw made in Inkscape using my extension here:

  • https://github.com/Neon22/inkscape-jigsaw
  • Requires Inkscape 0.91

Then exported in V7 of DanNewman's Inkscape to OpenSCAD converter here:

  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036

And then edited to make one side of the jigsaw cutter sharp.

You can make Jigsaw's of arbitrary size and shape by using the inkscape extension and a bit of manual editing. (Use the example scad as a guide) :)

Takes a while to F6...

Saw Spina's jigsaw and made one in OpenSCAD with my Inkscape extension - originally designed for laser cutters.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Choose the top and bottom line widths to better suit your print res.

The outline intially comes in as a solid block. So you could Minkowski your way around it.
But if you look at the file you can see what I did

  • which was to cut and paste some code from one of the other outlines
  • and replace the 4207 entity with a hulled line instead of a linear_extrude.

If you edit the file you can make the walls higher, or wider. All parameters are exposed at the top.

For more shapes, sizes, interlocking options - make it again in inkscape.

This is an earring stand for longer earrings. The stand was designed by a friend in Freehand and I just linear extruded them in openScad.

You can customize the lenght of the hangers if you want them shorter, or can print them longer. Also you can adjust the spacing between the holes and the radius of the holes.

Print stand.stl two times.

Print hanger.stl three times, or 3x_hangers.stl once.

Then just plug the hangers into the stands and you are done.

This is just a combination from different things to have the entire extruder in one place leaving out optional other parts.

It uses MoonCactus' Rollerstruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73082). But instead of the original base it uses the remix of the base from elephant (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:184298). The large gear I used is from foosel (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:151642) and the small gear again from MoonCactus (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45407). As well from MoonCactus is the design of the great hobbed bolt (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:68480).

In addition following parts are needed:

  • 3 ball bearings of type 608 ZZ (22x8x7 mm)
  • 1 cylinder head bolt M8x40 mm
  • 1 cylinder head bolt M8x30 mm
  • 1 countersunk screw M3x20 mm
  • 2 round head screws M3x16 mm
  • 3 round head screws M3x20 mm
  • 5 M3 nuts
  • 1 hex screw M6x70 mm
  • 1 wing nut M6
  • 2 washers with 6.4 mm innner and 17 mm outer diameter
  • 2 M8 washers
  • 1 pressure spring around 45 mm long, inner diameter at least 7 mm and 1 mm wire
  • 2 pieces of 50 mm 6x4 flexible silicon tube as thermal isolators between motor and frame

Note that you need a Dremel or Proxxon machine to produce the hobbed bolt. This is also described by MoonCactus in very detail.

Thanks a lot to MoonCactus for the fantastic work. The extruder works better than the original one and is much more quiet as well. With this extruder I could lower the current of the stepper driver and it gets much less hot now while it still does the job properly.

I hope it is ok to combine different things this way in a new thing. If not please drop me a short note what I need to do or if I have to remove the thing again.

author: adamkohm

description.text: I needed a handle for my stainless espresso tamp. The price of these things is quite a bit for what is essentially a hunk of plastic so I figured this would be a perfect time to design the 1st custom part my 3D printer would make. See video of the build process on my thingomatic: http://vimeo.com/25993602 It works amazingly well and fits perfectly into the stainless end. The only change I would make if I were to do it again would be to try my hand at designing some plastic threads to match with the included steel bolt...as it stands it works perfectly well using the bolt to cut its own threads into the handles base mounting hole.

The end is sized to approximately 30mm (standard RB tamper size) to fit the indent at the top of the tamp base. Be sure to double check that the object is sitting level on your build platform before building as I think the stl file may be set 1mm below origin.
Another small change one could make would be to extend the base of the tamper by a few millimeters to end up with a perfectly flush transition from the steel base into the plastic handle as my current version has a very small gap but I like the look of the small break.

author: RUDOLFSTEINER

title: XYZ Da Vinci 1.0A - E-Stepper Heatsink Mount

description.text:
I had snatched a 40x40mm aluminum heatsink from an old ATI graphics card and decided to employ its use. It had two snap-fit pins that I popped off, this is designed to loosely fit through those holes.

The heatsink still relies on some type of thermal paste to maintain a some-what stable connection, the mount prevents it from sliding down due to vibrations. I'm using Arctic Silver Ceramique and it has significantly reduced running temperatures of the stepper motor.

It has held up to around twenty hours of printing thus far with no significant slippage.

comments.text: how has this helped ? and have you seen any difference in anyway?
comments.author: Jun1322

comments.text: Why not mount the heatsink directly to the stepper using the stepper screws (or slightly longer ones)?  Works quite well and holds the heatsink tight to the motor.
comments.author: tbadera

comments.text: Granted that would offer a much better solution this was more or less a quick and dirty fix that didn't involve a run to the hardware store and still offered a more or less acceptable fix. Consider me lazy.
comments.author: tbadera

comments.text: I've done exactly that with a few steppers.  Remove 2 screws, add paste, add 2 longer screws, secure.  Makes a huge difference when you need to run your motors a bit hot.  Screwing it down also helps to squish the paste, affording better contact.
comments.author: tbadera
